Text: Byzantine–Hungarian War (1127–29):  Stephen II of Hungary broke into the empire in the summer.

Text: Byzantine–Hungarian War (1127–29):  His troops sacked Belgrade, Braničevo and Niš, and plundered the regions around Serdica (Sofia, Bulgaria) and Philippopolis (Plovdiv, Bulgaria), before returning to Hungary.

<Text: Byzantine–Hungarian War (1127–29):  In response, Emperor John II marched against Hungary in 1128, where he defeated the royal troops in a battle at Haram, and "captured Frangochorion, the richest land in Hungary" (now in Serbia).>

Text: Byzantine–Hungarian War (1127–29):  John Kinnamos wrote of a second campaign by Stephen against the Byzantine Empire, when the Hungarian troops, supported by Bohemian reinforcements under the command of Duke Václav of Olomouc, took Braničevo by storm and destroyed its fortress.
